Introduction

Chronic bacterial prostatitis (CBP) is a persistent (â‰¥3 months) bacterial infection of the prostate gland that is characterized by continuous or recurrent urogenital symptoms (eg, dysuria, perineal pain).  Unlike acute bacterial prostatitis (

), which typically presents with prominent systemic signs (eg, fever), CBP often manifests more subtly.  One of the hallmark clues to diagnosis is recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) caused by the same bacterial strain, despite appropriate antibiotic therapy.

Pathogenesis



The pathogenesis is not fully understood, but CBP often begins with an episode of acute bacterial prostatitis or a lower UTI that does not fully resolve.  Incomplete eradication may result from inadequate antibiotic therapy, antibiotic resistance, or anatomic and functional abnormalities of the urinary tract (eg, bladder outlet obstruction, intraprostatic reflux of contaminated urine).  The prostate contains a complex ductal network that is poorly penetrated by host immune defenses and many antibiotics.  This allows bacteria to persist within the gland, where many form biofilms that promote chronic infection, recurrence, and treatment failure.



The organisms responsible for CBP are typically the same as those causing most UTIs.  Infection usually occurs when coliform bacteria contaminate the urethra, then enter the prostate via intraprostatic reflux.  Escherichia coli is the most commonly isolated bacterium; other enteric organisms include Enterococcus faecalis, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Proteus mirabilis, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.  Atypical bacteria, including Chlamydia trachomatis, Ureaplasma urealyticum, Trichomonas vaginalis, and Mycoplasma genitalium, have also been implicated.

Risk factors



CBP is most common in young and middle-aged men.  Predisposing factors include:



  • Recurrent UTIs.
  • Previous episodes of acute bacterial prostatitis.
  • Impaired bladder emptying (eg, benign prostatic hyperplasia, urethral stricture).
  • Indwelling catheters, self-catheterization, or recent urologic instrumentation (eg, prostate biopsy, cystoscopy).
  • Immunosuppression and diabetes mellitus.

Pathology



Histologic examination shows varying degrees of inflammation within the prostate gland.  This includes lymphocytic and mononuclear infiltration, especially in the periductal areas.  Foci of bacterial colonization may also be present.

Clinical presentation



The presentation of CBP can vary and is often subtle.  Recurrent UTIs with the same bacterial strain, a hallmark feature, may be the first clue to a diagnosis.  Symptoms persist for â‰¥3 months and may be continuous or episodic (eg, symptoms improve but recur shortly after completing antibiotics); these include:



  • Dysuria, frequency, urgency, and nocturia.
  • Pelvic or perineal discomfort, which can radiate to the genitalia, anorectal area, or lower back.
  • Painful ejaculation or ejaculatory dysfunction (eg, delayed, premature).
  • Bloody ejaculate (hematospermia).
  • Absence of systemic symptoms (eg, fever, chills).


On digital rectal examination, the prostate is often normal (or mildly tender); significant tenderness, warmth, swelling, or bogginess suggests acute bacterial prostatitis.

Differential diagnosis



  • Chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ):  The most common form of chronic prostatitis, chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome presents similarly to CBP with pelvic pain and voiding symptoms.  However, no bacterial infection is detected on urine culture or in prostatic massage specimens.  This diagnosis of exclusion is thought to have a multifactorial etiology (eg, noninfectious inflammation, pelvic floor dysfunction, neuropathic pain).
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia (
    figure 1
    ):  Benign prostatic hyperplasia typically presents with irritative and obstructive urinary symptoms (eg, hesitancy, weak stream, incomplete bladder emptying) caused by mechanical compression of the urethra.  Pain is not a typical feature, and both urinalysis and urine cultures are generally normal.
  • Urethritis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ):  Usually associated with sexually transmitted infections (eg, C trachomatis, N gonorrhoeae), urethritis presents with dysuria and urethral discharge.  Because the infection is limited to the urethra, pelvic and perineal pain are uncommon.  Most cases respond to antibiotic therapy, and chronic or relapsing symptoms are rare.
  • Prostate cancer:  Often asymptomatic in its early stages, prostate cancer may present with obstructive urinary symptoms or back pain in advanced disease.  The prostate may be hard, irregular, or nodular on digital rectal examination, and urinalysis and urine cultures are typically negative.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of CBP should be considered in patients with persistent urogenital symptoms (eg, dysuria, perineal/pelvic pain) that recur or do not resolve after antibiotic therapy.

Laboratory evaluation



Urine culture remains the primary test for confirming a bacterial infection in the urine and identifying the causative organism.  Detection of the same uropathogen on repeated urine cultures in a symptomatic patient strongly supports the diagnosis of CBP.



The 2-glass test is the most common method for confirming a diagnosis of CBP.  It involves collecting 2 urine samples: 1 before and 1 after prostate massage.  During the massage, the provider gently presses on the prostate for approximately 1 minute to release prostatic secretions.  These secretions, along with the postmassage urine, are analyzed for bacterial content.  CBP is diagnosed when there is a â‰¥10-fold increase in bacterial count in the postmassage urine sample or in expressed prostatic secretions compared to the premassage urine sample.



In patients with persistent symptoms strongly suggestive of CBP but with negative urine cultures and an unrevealing 2-glass test, PCR testing for atypical pathogens (eg, C trachomatis, M genitalium) should be considered to detect organisms not identified by standard culture methods.

Imaging studies



Imaging studies are not routinely required because CBP is typically diagnosed based on clinical presentation and microbiologic testing.  However, imaging can be helpful in complex, atypical, or treatment-resistant cases to evaluate for underlying structural abnormalities or complications.  For example, transrectal ultrasonography may be used to detect prostatic calculi, abscesses, and ductal obstruction, which can serve as reservoirs for persistent infection or contribute to poor antibiotic penetration.  Cystoscopy allows for direct visualization of the urinary tract and may be warranted to rule out urothelial malignancy or structural abnormalities (eg, bladder neck obstruction, urethral strictures).

Management



The cornerstone of treatment for CBP is prolonged antibiotic therapy, usually for 4-6 weeks.  Fluoroquinolones (eg, ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin) are commonly used due to their excellent prostatic penetration and activity against gram-negative bacteria.  Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is an alternate agent that also achieves high penetration levels within the prostate, but antibiotic resistance may limit its effectiveness.  Culture with sensitivity profile should be considered prior to initiating therapy.



Sexually transmitted infections are managed with the usual agents (eg, doxycycline for C trachomatis), but the course of treatment is also extended to 4-6 weeks.  Adjunctive therapies include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs to control pain and alpha-blockers (eg, tamsulosin) to improve voiding symptoms and relieve bladder outlet resistance.  Surgical intervention to correct anatomic or functional obstruction should be considered in refractory cases.

Prognosis



The prognosis of CBP is variable and depends on factors such as the infecting organism, presence of anatomic abnormalities, and response to antibiotic therapy.  Many patients experience symptom improvement with prolonged antibiotic treatment.  However, recurrence is common (20%-50% of cases) and often necessitates a second extended course of antibiotics.  Some patients continue to experience chronic pelvic or urogenital symptoms even after bacterial eradication (ie, negative cultures), likely representing a transition to chronic pelvic pain syndrome, which can significantly impact quality of life.

Prevention



Prevention of CBP primarily involves appropriate and timely treatment of UTIs and acute bacterial prostatitis, avoidance of unnecessary catheterization/urologic instrumentation, and prompt identification and management of anatomic/functional abnormalities (eg, urinary retention/reflux, bladder outlet obstruction, benign prostatic hyperplasia).

Summary



Chronic bacterial prostatitis (

) is characterized by relapsing episodes of urinary symptoms (eg, dysuria, frequency) and pelvic/perineal discomfort for â‰¥3 months due to a persistent bacterial infection of the prostate gland.  Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating a â‰¥10-fold increase in bacterial count in urine collected before versus after prostatic massage.  Prolonged antibiotic therapy, typically for 4-6 weeks, is required to eradicate infection, although recurrence is common.
